timeline.subject: Blasotte femme Claudon Collon
timeline.details: Witness depositions began, taken by maire and gens de justice of ban de Moyenmoustier

timeline.subject: Blasotte femme Claudon Collon
timeline.details: Confrontations with witnesses; generally denied allegations; seemed to lose consciousness, had blood on tooth from 'mal St. Jean'

timeline.subject: Blasotte femme Claudon Collon
timeline.details: Procureur d'office of abbé (Nicolas Bernard) asks for question extraordinaire

timeline.subject: Blasotte femme Claudon Collon
timeline.details: Change de Nancy agrees to torture, though it should be 'mediocrement'

timeline.subject: Blasotte femme Claudon Collon
timeline.details: Interrogation under torture; racked but would not confess; brought back after dinner and racked again despite marginal notes from Change clerk; mentioned bird in prison that encouraged her

timeline.subject: Blasotte femme Claudon Collon
timeline.details: Placed on rack (not tortured) and confessed to being witch for 3/7 years; confessed to malefices and sabbat attendance; named accomplices

timeline.subject: Blasotte femme Claudon Collon
timeline.details: Confronted with three named accomplices; persisted despite their denials

timeline.subject: Blasotte femme Claudon Collon
timeline.details: Case presented to 'bons hommes' of ban and seigneurie, who called for death sentence

timeline.subject: Blasotte femme Claudon Collon
timeline.details: Procureur d'office asks for death sentence

timeline.subject: Blasotte femme Claudon Collon
timeline.details: Change de Nancy agrees to death sentence, but she should first confirm confession in place other than torture chamber without intimidation

timeline.subject: Blasotte femme Claudon Collon
timeline.details: Repeated confession and accusations; confronted afresh with Blason and Jehenne Charpentier, persisted in charging them

torture.requesting_official: Nicolas Bernard, procureur d'office of abbé

accomplices_named.name: Jehenne Charpentier
accomplices_named.context: wife of Demenge le Maire; seen at sabbat

accomplices_named.name: woman from St. Blaise
accomplices_named.context: identified by Jehenne at sabbat, but Blasotte forgot her name

accomplices_named.name: Claudel Demenge Martin
accomplices_named.context: seen at sabbat; initially said Idoult Demenge Martin but corrected herself

prior_accusations.context: she feared being broken ('deromperoit') as they had her brother for the same charge

notable_quotes.speaker: Demenge Jean Claude
notable_quotes.french: fault il que tu fasse les meschants le coeur jouyr
notable_quotes.context: Demenge confronting sister who was beating her daughter after quarrel with Blasotte

notable_quotes.speaker: Blasotte to Blason Charpentier's wife
notable_quotes.french: qu'elle ne mourroit d'autres mains que des siennes
notable_quotes.english: she would die by no other hands than hers

notable_quotes.speaker: Blasotte to Jennon wife of Claudon Pellier
notable_quotes.french: que mal joye et mal chance puisse tu avoir, et puisse tu retourner de lict
notable_quotes.english: may you have bad joy and bad luck, and may you return to bed
notable_quotes.context: Threat to pregnant woman who then had premature child

notable_quotes.speaker: Blasotte to daughter who gossiped
notable_quotes.english: she would make the girl wither
notable_quotes.context: After girl told others about Blasotte's prediction of cow's death

notable_quotes.speaker: Claudon Gerardin to Blasotte
notable_quotes.french: qu'il chie sur les cloches, et qu'elle aymeroit aultant qu'il ne sonne pas
notable_quotes.context: Dispute over dues; he responded 'ainsy font les sorcieres' (thus do witches)

notable_quotes.speaker: Claudon Gerardin to Blasotte
notable_quotes.french: Sorciere advise qu'il ne m'arrive encore telle fortune que j'ay heu, ou altrement je te feray mourir
notable_quotes.english: Witch beware that such misfortune does not happen to me again, or else I will have you killed
notable_quotes.context: After various misfortunes when collecting dues

notable_quotes.speaker: Mongeatte wife of Noel George
notable_quotes.french: Ay l'at elle dict Je la feray seichir toute droicte
notable_quotes.english: Yes did she say it, I will make her wither completely
notable_quotes.context: Blasotte's response about making girl who gossiped become ill

notable_quotes.speaker: Claudon Valtin le Jeune, quoting quarrel
notable_quotes.french: Genaxe tu as eu aultres fois menassé la fille de Colas du Mesnil que tu la ferois seichir ce qu'elle a esté
notable_quotes.context: Noel George's wife to Blasotte; reply was 'c'est vray, elle a seiché voirement'

notable_quotes.speaker: Jean le Maire to Blasotte
notable_quotes.context: Blasotte feared arrest as they had broken her brother for same charge

relationships.evidence_text: daughter of Idoult le Chouche and his wife Jelon

his small child, whose godmother she was
had been doing day work in Blasotte's house

economic_context.details: Multiple disputes over straying animals, fines for animal damage, taxes, dues collection, theft accusations (pears, acorns, wood, oats, iron bands). Blasotte had sold planks as widow, suggesting some property. Disputes over customary dues and tithe collection indicate economic tensions in community.

material_culture.context: Blasotte came in with handful of hair during thunderstorm, made great smell when put on fire
she had learned from her father to throw hail on fire to make storm cease
approached Blason Charpentier's wife with stones in her hands
Demenge Reullemant went to buy planks from her when she was widow
dispute over taking pears from tree; mother ate fallen pear
quarrel over taking acorns from tree
Claudon Peltier accused her of stealing his iron bands
reproaching her for taking wood from around field
remedy for cow losing milk - beat animal with stick made from 'bois de core'
confessed to killing animals with powder given by devil
refused to take her son when taking cart to woods
Blasotte put hand near cradle at inn
Colas George made her pay a 'passaige' of 30 gros
Colas George complained she gave no bread when children guarded her beasts
she helped load sheaves for Claudon Gerardin's son

extraction_metadata.notes: Trial w160, Blasotte femme Claudon Collon of La Chapelle, 1596. Extensive witness testimony (48 witnesses) with detailed harms catalog. Reputation spanning 12-20 years. Key features: torture with Change de Nancy oversight and marginal notes criticizing procedure; confession only after being placed on rack; named 4 accomplices; brother previously executed for witchcraft; husband called her witch. Economic disputes prominent throughout (taxes, dues, straying animals, theft). Multiple animal deaths described as 'rabid'. Hearsay chains documented. Document ends with confirmation of confession on 2 December 1596.
